title: Dalkeith Country Park Walk Route

images.title: Kay Williams / The Conservatory, Dalkeith country park
images.caption: The Conservatory, Dalkeith country park. Conservatory, now ruined, built about 1832 to a design by William Burn and used to grow exotic fruits for the Duke of Buccleuch at Dalkeith House. The boiler was said to consume up to a ton of coal a day.

images.title: Kay Williams / Laundry House, Dalkeith country park
images.caption: Named as the Laundry House on detailed map. Classic Georgian design for the Duke of Buccleuch at Dalkeith House.

images.title: M J Richardson / Ancient Oaks in Dalkeith Country Park
images.caption: Ancient Oaks in Dalkeith Country Park. Some of the many very old oaks in this park, a lot now showing signs of their age.

images.title: Jim Barton / Ice house in Dalkeith Country Park
images.caption: Ice house in the park. Used for storing ice in the days before refrigerators, this would be an essential item for catering for the needs of Dalkeith House.

images.title: Sandy Gemmill / King's Gate entrance to Dalkeith Park
images.caption: The view of the King's Gate entrance to Dalkeith Park. The gatehouse is on the right.

images.title: Richard Webb / Control punching, Dalkeith Park
images.caption: Control punching, Dalkeith Park An orienteering control in action: competitors prove they have completed the course by placing a chip into a box at the flag. The memory chip carried by the runner then has the time of visit recorded. At the finish, the time is calculated by computer and the runner gets a printout of all the times between controls on the course. Orienteering is cross country running, where shortcuts are allowed. The course is defined by a series of flags. You have to visit the flags in order,as fast as possible, the trick being to also work out from a map the quickest route.

images.title: Sandy Gemmill / The Montagu Bridge
images.caption: The Montagu bridge in Dalkeith Country Park crosses the North Esk river. The bridge was built in 1792 and was a gift from the Montagu family on the occurrence of a marriage between their family and the Queensberry family.

images.title: M J Richardson / Once upon a time..
images.caption: Once upon a time.. ..there was a bridge across the River South Esk, just above its junction with the River North Esk at the Meeting of the Waters. All that remains now are the two pillars that supported it.

description: This large country park near Edinburgh has a number of excellent walking and cycling paths. The waymarked walking trails run through the ancient oak woodland and along the River Esk which runs through the park. Cyclists can follow the miles of estate roads and then follow a lovely off road path along the River Esk to Musselburgh on the coast. Look out for an abundance of wildlife including deer, foxes, herons and otters. To extend your walking in the area you could head into Holyrood Park in the city and  climb to Arthur's Seat. This splendid hike is a real highlight of the area, commanding fine views over city and the coast. Also nearby is Bonaly Country Park where there are more good cycling and walking trails to try.
